description: 1571, in sense of “to take back to prison”, from Middle English repryen (“to remand, detain”) (1494), probably from Middle French repris, form of reprendre (“take back”); cognate to reprise. Sense generalized, but retains connotations of punishment and execution. Noun attested 1598. Compare to Latin privare.

entries.meaning: The cancellation or postponement of a punishment.
examples: The prisoner was saved from execution; the governor had requested a reprieve.

entries.meaning: A document authorizing such an action.
Relief from pain etc., especially temporary.
A cancellation or postponement of a proposed event undesired by many.

verbs.description: reprieve (third-person singular simple present reprieves, present participle reprieving, simple past and past participle reprieved)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cancel or postpone the punishment of someone, especially an execution.
(transitive, obsolete) To take back to prison (in lieu of execution).
To abandon or postpone plans to close, withdraw or abolish (something).
